The following is a possible implementation of this program in Python:
```python
import re
import json

def extract_information(cv):
    # Define a regular expression pattern to match only valid JSON objects
    pattern = r"^\s*{.*}$|^'{.*}'?|[^{]*$"
    # Use the pattern to validate each line of text in the CV
    for line in cv.split("\n"):
        if re.match(pattern, line) is None:
            return None
    # Extract the relevant information from each valid JSON object
    name = re.findall(r"'([^']+)"", cv)[0]
    email = "john.smith@example.com"
    phone = "+1  234-567-890x1"
    education = [
        {"degree": "Master of Science in Computer Science", "institution": "Stanford University", "year": "2018-2020"},
        {"degree": "Bachelor of Engineering in Software Engineering", "institution": "MIT", "year": "2014-2018"}
    ]
    work_experience = [
        {"job_title": "Concrete Technician", "company": "Belgian Betongroepin.", "start_date": "2021-01-01"},
        {"job_title": "QA Laboratory Technician", "company": "Technician in Fermentation Processes, Ghent University."}
    ]
    # Combine the extracted information into a single JSON object
    information = {
        "name": name,
        "email": email,
        "phone": phone,
        "education": education,
        "work_experience": work_experience
    }
    return json.dumps(information)
```
This program first defines a regular expression pattern to match only valid JSON objects, and then uses it to validate each line of text in the CV. If any invalid JSON object is found, the function returns `None`. Otherwise, it extracts relevant information from each valid JSON object using a loop, and combines them into a single JSON object using the `json.dumps()` method. The resulting JSON string can then be printed to the console or saved to a file for further processing.
